Space-efficient representation of tensors of matrices
Suppose we have representations of G, \rho and \tau, with degree n and m. If we would like to construct the tensor product representation of G, \rho \otimes \tau, the usual way to do it would be to take the Kronecker product of the matrices. This means we now have to store very large nm \times nm matrices for each generator of G. This can be avoided by storing the tensor of matrices as pairs, essentially storing A \otimes B as a pair (A,B) and implementing group operations on top of these, along with some representation-theoretic functions. Even though matrices do form a ring, it is only possible to guarantee an economical representation for pure tensors, i.e. matrices of the form A \otimes B. These are closed under group operations, so it is natural to define a group structure.
